p: “Traditional” interval cohort studies, like the MWCCS, that implement protocols that specify the timing and type of data collection have been a mainstay of epidemiologic inference for over 80 years ( 45). With the rise of electronic medical and administrative records, clinical cohort studies have arisen to capitalize on the opportunity to utilize these data for epidemiologic inference ( 46). HIV study has benefitted tremendously with the establishment of studies using clinical populations and measurements, such as the single-site Johns Hopkins Clinical Cohort Study ( 47) as well as multicenter studies such as the Centers for AIDS Research Network of Integrated Clinical Systems (CNICS) Cohort Study ( 48).
